title: “old me” and the “new me”
content:
“old me” and the “new me”
[旧我与新我]
Before becoming self-aware, there’s no clear distinction between the “old me” and the “new me”—everything just happens naturally.
[在没有觉察的时候，没有新我与旧我的区别，一切都是自然地发生。]
But once awareness arises, a sense of inner split often emerges—as if there are multiple versions of yourself in your mind, some familiar, some strange.
[但有了觉察之后，有时会出现明显的割裂感，仿佛自己脑子里住着不同的人，有的熟悉，有的陌生。]
This happens because awareness creates an observing self, one that can view your choices, desires, and words from a godlike, outside perspective.
[这是因为觉察带来了一个“观察者意识”，能以一种上帝视角从外部观察自己的选择、欲望和说话方式。]
So “you” are no longer a single entity, but a system composed of:
[于是，“我”不再是一个单一角色，而是由多个部分构成：]
 The “old me” driven by desire;
[ 一个被欲望驱动的“旧我”；]
The “new me” that you aspire to become;
[一个在认知与理想中想要成为的“新我”；]
And the “observer” who watches them both.
[还有一个“观察这两者”的觉察者。]
This marks a structural split in your psyche.
[这就带来了心理结构的裂变。]
There are three reasons why the “new me” can feel unfamiliar:
[而对新我感到陌生，有三个原因：]
First, the new self lacks bodily memory—your brain doesn’t yet default to its choices and behaviors.
[第一，新我缺乏身体记忆，没有经历足够的选择与行为的积累，还没成为大脑的“默认选项”。]
Second, the new self is built from the old system, so if judged by old patterns, it feels alien, fake, or “not really me.”
[第二，新我是从旧结构中诞生的新结构，用旧的认知去评判时会觉得它是异类、陌生、不真实。]
Adjusting to new cognition takes time and practice.
[刷新认知和适应认知需要时间和练习。]
Third, social identity can pull you back toward the old self—though in my case, this has less influence.
[第三，是社会身份习惯的拉扯，会让你在外在形象中维持旧的自我——在我这里这种影响较小。]
In the tug-of-war between old and new selves, it’s essential to gently nurture the growth of the new self.
[在这种新我与旧我的撕裂中，需要小心呵护新我的成长。]
Give it time to take root and mature.
[需要给它一些时间去发育和成长。]
